member.name: T:Elm.Core.Basics.Never
member.summary: A value that can never happen!

member.name: T:Elm.Core.Basics.Order
member.summary: Represents the relative ordering of two things. The relations are less than, equal to, and greater than.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.never``1(Elm.Core.Basics.Never)
member.summary: So the `never` function is basically telling the type system, make sure no one ever calls me!

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.always``2(``0,``1)
member.summary: Create a function that *always* returns the same value.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.identity``1(``0)
member.summary: Given a value, returns exactly the same value. This is called [the identity function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity_function).

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.isInfinite(System.Double)
member.summary: Determine whether a float is positive or negative infinity.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.isNaN(System.Double)
member.summary: Determine whether a float is an undefined or unrepresentable number. NaN stands for *not a number* and it is [a standardized part of floating point numbers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NaN).

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.toPolar(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Convert Cartesian coordinates (x,y) to polar coordinates (r,θ).

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.fromPolar(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Convert polar coordinates (r,θ) to Cartesian coordinates (x,y).

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.turns(System.Double)
member.summary: Convert turns to standard Elm angles (radians). One turn is equal to 360Â°.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.degrees(System.Double)
member.summary: Convert degrees to standard Elm angles (radians).

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.radians``1(``0)
member.summary: Convert radians to standard Elm angles (radians).

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.atan2(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: This helps you find the angle (in radians) to an `(x,y)` coordinate. So rather than saying `atan (y/x)` you say `atan2 y x` and you can get a full range of angles.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.atan(System.Double)
member.summary: This helps you find the angle (in radians) to an `(x,y)` coordinate, but in a way that is rarely useful in programming. **You probably want [`atan2`](#atan2) instead!**

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.asin(System.Double)
member.summary: Figure out the arcsine for `opposite / hypotenuse` in radians.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.acos(System.Double)
member.summary: Figure out the arccosine for `adjacent / hypotenuse` in radians.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.tan(System.Double)
member.summary: Figure out the tangent given an angle in radians.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.sin(System.Double)
member.summary: Figure out the sine given an angle in radians.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.cos(System.Double)
member.summary: Figure out the cosine given an angle in radians.

member.name: P:Elm.Core.Basics.pi
member.summary: An approximation of pi.

member.name: P:Elm.Core.Basics.e
member.summary: An approximation of e.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.logBase(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate the logarithm of a number with a given base.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.sqrt``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``1},``0)
member.summary: Take the square root of a number.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.clamp``1(``0,``0,``0)
member.summary: Clamps a number within a given range.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.abs``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``0},``0)
member.summary: Get the [absolute value][abs] of a number.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.negate``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``0},``0)
member.summary: Negate a number.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.remainderBy(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the remainder after division.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.modBy(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Perform [modular arithmetic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_arithmetic). A common trick is to use (n mod 2) to detect even and odd numbers.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.xor(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: The exclusive-or operator.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.compare``1(``0,``0)
member.summary: Compare any two comparable values.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.truncate(System.Double)
member.summary: Truncate a number, rounding towards zero.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.ceiling(System.Double)
member.summary: Ceiling function, rounding up.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.floor(System.Double)
member.summary: Floor function, rounding down.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.round(System.Double)
member.summary: Round a number to the nearest integer.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.toFloat(System.Int32)
member.summary: Convert an integer into a float.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.op_Concatenate(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Exponentiation

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.op_PlusPlus``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``0}},``0,``0)
member.summary: Put two appendable things together. This includes strings and lists.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.op_DivisionAssignment``1(``0,``0)
member.summary: Check if values are not the same.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.op_EqualsEquals``1(``0,``0)
member.summary: Check if values are the same.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.idiv(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Integer division. Notice that the remainder is discarded.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.fdiv(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Floating-point division.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.mul(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Multiply numbers like `2 * 3 == 6`.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.sub(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Subtract numbers like `4 - 3 == 1`.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Basics.add(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Add two numbers.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Maybe.andThen``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpOption{``1}},Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpOption{``0})
member.summary: Chain together many computations that may fail. It is helpful to see its definition: <para>andThen : (a -> Maybe b) -> Maybe a -> Maybe b</para> <para>andThen callback maybe =</para> <para> case maybe of</para> <para> Just value -></para> <para> callback value</para> <para> Nothing -></para> <para> Nothing</para> This means we only continue with the callback if things are going well. For example, say you need to parse some user input as a month: <para>parseMonth : String -> Maybe Int</para> <para>parseMonth userInput =</para> <para> String.toInt userInput</para> <para> |> andThen toValidMonth</para> <para>toValidMonth : Int -> Maybe Int</para> <para>toValidMonth month =</para> <para> if 1 <= month && month <= 12 then</para> <para> Just month</para> <para> else</para> <para> Nothing</para> In the `parseMonth` function, if `String.toInt` produces `Nothing` (because the `userInput` was not an integer) this entire chain of operations will short-circuit and result in `Nothing`. If `toValidMonth` results in `Nothing`, again the chain of computations will result in `Nothing`.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Maybe.map2``3(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``1,``2}},Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpOption{``0},Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpOption{``1})
member.summary: Apply a function if all the arguments are `Just` a value. <para>map2 (+) (Just 3) (Just 4) == Just 7</para> <para>map2 (+) (Just 3) Nothing == Nothing</para> <para>map2 (+) Nothing (Just 4) == Nothing</para> <para>map2 (+) (String.toInt "1") (String.toInt "123") == Just 124</para> <para>map2 (+) (String.toInt "x") (String.toInt "123") == Nothing</para> <para>map2 (+) (String.toInt "1") (String.toInt "1.3") == Nothing</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Maybe.map``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``1},Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpOption{``0})
member.summary: Transform a `Maybe` value with a given function: <para>map sqrt (Just 9) == Just 3</para> <para>map sqrt Nothing == Nothing</para> <para>map sqrt (String.toFloat "9") == Just 3</para> <para>map sqrt (String.toFloat "x") == Nothing</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Maybe.withDefault``1(``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpOption{``0})
member.summary: Provide a default value, turning an optional value into a normal value. This comes in handy when paired with functions like [`Dict.get`](Dict#get) which gives back a `Maybe`. <para>withDefault 100 (Just 42) -- 42</para> <para>withDefault 100 Nothing -- 100</para> <para>withDefault "unknown" (Dict.get "Tom" Dict.empty) -- "unknown"</para> **Note:** This can be overused! Many cases are better handled by a `case` expression. And if you end up using `withDefault` a lot, it can be a good sign that a [custom type][ct] will clean your code up quite a bit! [ct]: https://guide.elm-lang.org/types/custom_types.html

member.name: T:Elm.Core.MaybePervasives.Maybe`1
member.summary: Represent values that may or may not exist. It can be useful if you have a record field that is only filled in sometimes. Or if a function takes a value sometimes, but does not absolutely need it. <para>-- A person, but maybe we do not know their age.</para> <para>type Person =</para> <para> { name : String</para> <para> , age : Maybe Int</para> <para> }</para> <para>let tom = { name = "Tom", age = Just 42 }</para> <para>let sue = { name = "Sue", age = Nothing }</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Char.fromCode(System.Int32)
member.summary: Convert a Unicode [code point][cp] to a character.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Char.toLower(System.Char)
member.summary: Convert to lower case.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Char.toUpper(System.Char)
member.summary: Convert to upper case.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Char.isHexDigit(System.Char)
member.summary: Detect hexadecimal digits `0123456789abcdefABCDEF`

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Char.isOctDigit(System.Char)
member.summary: Detect octal digits `01234567`.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Char.isAlphaNum(System.Char)
member.summary: Detect upper case and lower case ASCII characters.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Char.isDigit(System.Char)
member.summary: Detect digits `0123456789`

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Char.isAlpha(System.Char)
member.summary: Detect upper case and lower case ASCII characters.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Char.isLower(System.Char)
member.summary: Detect lower case ASCII characters.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Char.isUpper(System.Char)
member.summary: Detect upper case ASCII characters.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Char.toCode(System.Char)
member.summary: Convert to the corresponding Unicode [code point][cp].

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.fromFloat(System.Double)
member.summary: Convert a `Float` to a `String`. <para>String.fromFloat 123 == "123"</para> <para>String.fromFloat -42 == "-42"</para> <para>String.fromFloat 3.9 == "3.9"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.toFloat(System.String)
member.summary: Try to convert a string into a float, failing on improperly formatted strings. <para>String.toFloat "123" == Just 123.0</para> <para>String.toFloat "-42" == Just -42.0</para> <para>String.toFloat "3.1" == Just 3.1</para> <para>String.toFloat "31a" == Nothing</para> If you are extracting a number from some raw user input, you will typically want to use [`Maybe.withDefault`](Maybe#withDefault) to handle bad data: <para>Maybe.withDefault 0 (String.toFloat "42.5") == 42.5</para> <para>Maybe.withDefault 0 (String.toFloat "cats") == 0</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.fromInt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Convert an `Int` to a `String`. <para>String.fromInt 123 == "123"</para> <para>String.fromInt -42 == "-42"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.toInt(System.String)
member.summary: Try to convert a string into an int, failing on improperly formatted strings. <para>String.toInt "123" == Just 123</para> <para>String.toInt "-42" == Just -42</para> <para>String.toInt "3.1" == Nothing</para> <para>String.toInt "31a" == Nothing</para> If you are extracting a number from some raw user input, you will typically want to use [`Maybe.withDefault`](Maybe#withDefault) to handle bad data: <para>Maybe.withDefault 0 (String.toInt "42") == 42</para> <para>Maybe.withDefault 0 (String.toInt "ab") == 0</para> <para>String.fromInt 123 == "123"</para> <para>String.fromInt -42 == "-42"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.trimRight(System.String)
member.summary: Get rid of whitespace on the right of a string. <para>trimRight " hats \n" == " hats"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.trimLeft(System.String)
member.summary: Get rid of whitespace on the left of a string. <para>trimLeft " hats \n" == "hats \n"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.trim(System.String)
member.summary: Get rid of whitespace on both sides of a string. <para>trim " hats \n" == "hats"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.padRight(System.Int32,System.Char,System.String)
member.summary: Pad a string on the right until it has a given length. <para>padRight 5 '.' "1" == "1...."</para> <para>padRight 5 '.' "11" == "11..."</para> <para>padRight 5 '.' "121" == "121.."</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.padLeft(System.Int32,System.Char,System.String)
member.summary: Pad a string on the left until it has a given length. <para>padLeft 5 '.' "1" == "....1"</para> <para>padLeft 5 '.' "11" == "...11"</para> <para>padLeft 5 '.' "121" == "..121"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.pad(System.Int32,System.Char,System.String)
member.summary: Pad a string on both sides until it has a given length. <para>pad 5 ' ' "1" == " 1 "</para> <para>pad 5 ' ' "11" == " 11 "</para> <para>pad 5 ' ' "121" == " 121 "</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.toLower(System.String)
member.summary: Convert a string to all lower case. Useful for case-insensitive comparisons. <para>toLower "X-FILES" == "x-files"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.toUpper(System.String)
member.summary: Convert a string to all upper case. Useful for case-insensitive comparisons and VIRTUAL YELLING. <para>toUpper "skinner" == "SKINNER"</para>

member.name: P:Elm.Core.String.indices
member.summary: Alias for `indexes`.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.indexes(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Get all of the indexes for a substring in another string. <para>indexes "i" "Mississippi" == [1,4,7,10]</para> <para>indexes "ss" "Mississippi" == [2,5]</para> <para>indexes "needle" "haystack" == []</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.contains(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: See if the second string contains the first one. <para>contains "the" "theory" == True</para> <para>contains "hat" "theory" == False</para> <para>contains "THE" "theory" == False</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.endsWith(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: See if the second string ends with the first one. <para>endsWith "the" "theory" == False</para> <para>endsWith "ory" "theory" == True</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.startsWith(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: See if the second string starts with the first one. <para>startsWith "the" "theory" == True</para> <para>startsWith "ory" "theory" == False</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.dropRight(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Drop *n* characters from the right side of a string. <para>dropRight 2 "Cigarette Smoking Man" == "Cigarette Smoking M"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.dropLeft(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Drop *n* characters from the left side of a string. <para>dropLeft 2 "The Lone Gunmen" == "e Lone Gunmen"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.right(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Take *n* characters from the right side of a string. <para>right 2 "Scully" == "ly"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.left(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Take *n* characters from the left side of a string. <para>left 2 "Mulder" == "Mu"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.slice(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Take a substring given a start and end index. Negative indexes are taken starting from the *end* of the string.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.lines(System.String)
member.summary: Break a string into lines, splitting on newlines. <para>lines "How are you?\nGood?" == ["How are you?", "Good?"]</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.words(System.String)
member.summary: Break a string into words, splitting on chunks of whitespace. <para>words "How are \t you? \n Good?" == ["How","are","you?","Good?"]</para>

member.name: P:Elm.Core.String.concat
member.summary: Concatenate many strings into one. <para>concat ["never","the","less"] == "nevertheless"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.append(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Append two strings. <para>append "butter" "fly" == "butterfly"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.replace(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Replace all occurrences of some substring. <para>replace "." "-" "Json.Decode.succeed" == "Json-Decode-succeed"</para> <para>replace "," "/" "a,b,c,d,e" == "a/b/c/d/e"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.join(System.String,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{System.String})
member.summary: Put many strings together with a given separator. <para>join "a" ["H","w","ii","n"] == "Hawaiian"</para> <para>join " " ["cat","dog","cow"] == "cat dog cow"</para> <para>join "/" ["home","evan","Desktop"] == "home/evan/Desktop"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.split(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Split a string using a given separator. <para>split "," "cat,dog,cow" == ["cat","dog","cow"]</para> <para>split "/" "home/evan/Desktop/" == ["home","evan","Desktop", ""]</para>

member.name: P:Elm.Core.String.repeat
member.summary: Repeat a string *n* times.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.reverse(System.String)
member.summary: Reverse a string. <para>reverse "stressed" == "desserts"</para>

member.name: P:Elm.Core.String.length
member.summary: Get the length of a string. <para>length "innumerable" == 11</para> <para>length "" == 0</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.isEmpty(System.String)
member.summary: Determine if a string is empty.

member.name: P:Elm.Core.String.all
member.summary: Determine whether *all* characters pass the test. <para>all isDigit "90210" == True</para> <para>all isDigit "R2-D2" == False</para> <para>all isDigit "heart" == False</para>

member.name: P:Elm.Core.String.any
member.summary: Determine whether *any* characters pass the test. <para>any isDigit "90210" == True</para> <para>any isDigit "R2-D2" == True</para> <para>any isDigit "heart" == False</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.foldr``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{System.Char,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``0}},``0,System.String)
member.summary: Reduce a string from the right. <para>foldr cons "" "time" == "time"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.foldl``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{System.Char,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``0}},``0,System.String)
member.summary: Reduce a string from the left. <para>foldl cons "" "time" == "emit"</para>

member.name: P:Elm.Core.String.filter
member.summary: Keep only the characters that pass the test. <para>filter isDigit "R2-D2" == "22"</para>

member.name: P:Elm.Core.String.map
member.summary: Transform every character in a string <para>map (fun c -> if c == '/' then '.' else c) "a/b/c" == "a.b.c"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.fromList(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{System.Char})
member.summary: Convert a list of characters into a String. Can be useful if you want to create a string primarily by consing, perhaps for decoding something. <para>fromList ['a','b','c'] == "abc"</para> <para>fromList ['ðŸ™ˆ','ðŸ™‰','ðŸ™Š'] == "ðŸ™ˆðŸ™‰ðŸ™Š"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.toList(System.String)
member.summary: Convert a string to a list of characters. <para>toList "abc" == ['a','b','c']</para> <para>toList "ðŸ™ˆðŸ™‰ðŸ™Š" == ['ðŸ™ˆ','ðŸ™‰','ðŸ™Š']</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.fromChar(System.Char)
member.summary: Create a string from a given character. <para>fromChar 'a' == "a"</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.cons(System.Char,System.String)
member.summary: Add a character to the beginning of a string. cons 'T' "he truth is out there" == "The truth is out there"

member.name: M:Elm.Core.String.uncons(System.String)
member.summary: Split a non-empty string into its head and tail. This lets you pattern match on strings exactly as you would with lists. <para>uncons "abc" == Just ('a',"bc")</para> <para>uncons "" == Nothing</para>

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Tuple.mapBoth``4(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``1},Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``2,``3},``0,``2)
member.summary: Transform both parts of a tuple. import String mapBoth String.reverse sqrt ("stressed", 16) == ("desserts", 4) mapBoth String.length negate ("stressed", 16) == (8, -16)

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Tuple.mapSecond``3(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``1},``2,``0)
member.summary: Transform the second value in a tuple. mapSecond sqrt ("stressed", 16) == ("stressed", 4) mapSecond negate ("stressed", 16) == ("stressed", -16)

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Tuple.mapFirst``3(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``1},``0,``2)
member.summary: Transform the first value in a tuple. import String mapFirst String.reverse ("stressed", 16) == ("desserts", 16) mapFirst String.length ("stressed", 16) == (8, 16)

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Tuple.second``2(``0,``1)
member.summary: Extract the second value from a tuple. second (3, 4) == 4 second ("john", "doe") == "doe"

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Tuple.first``2(``0,``1)
member.summary: Extract the first value from a tuple. first (3, 4) == 3 first ("john", "doe") == "john"

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Tuple.pair``2(``0,``1)
member.summary: Create a 2-tuple. -- pair 3 4 == (3, 4) zip : List a -> List b -> List (a, b) zip xs ys = List.map2 Tuple.pair xs ys

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Array.slice``1(System.Int32,System.Int32,``0[])
member.summary: Get a sub-section of an array: `(slice start end array)`. The `start` is a zero-based index where we will start our slice. The `end` is a zero-based index that indicates the end of the slice. The slice extracts up to but not including `end`. slice 0 3 (fromList [0,1,2,3,4]) == fromList [0,1,2] slice 1 4 (fromList [0,1,2,3,4]) == fromList [1,2,3] Both the `start` and `end` indexes can be negative, indicating an offset from the end of the array. slice 1 -1 (fromList [0,1,2,3,4]) == fromList [1,2,3] slice -2 5 (fromList [0,1,2,3,4]) == fromList [3,4] This makes it pretty easy to `pop` the last element off of an array: `slice 0 -1 array`

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Array.translateIndex``1(System.Int32,``0[])
member.summary: Given a relative array index, convert it into an absolute one. translateIndex -1 someArray == someArray.length - 1 translateIndex -10 someArray == someArray.length - 10 translateIndex 5 someArray == 5

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Array.indexedMap``2
member.summary: Apply a function on every element with its index as first argument. indexedMap (*) (fromList [5,5,5]) == fromList [0,5,10]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Array.foldl``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``1,``1}},``1,``0[])
member.summary: Reduce an array from the left. Read `foldl` as fold from the left. foldl (::) [] (fromList [1,2,3]) == [3,2,1]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Array.foldr``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``1,``1}},``0[],``1)
member.summary: Reduce an array from the right. Read `foldr` as fold from the right. foldr (+) 0 (repeat 3 5) == 15

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Array.toIndexedList``1(``0[])
member.summary: Create an indexed list from an array. Each element of the array will be paired with its index. toIndexedList (fromList ["cat","dog"]) == [(0,"cat"), (1,"dog")]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Array.push``1(``0,``0[])
member.summary: Push an element onto the end of an array. push 3 (fromList [1,2]) == fromList [1,2,3]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Array.set``1(System.Int32,``0,``0[])
member.summary: Set the element at a particular index. Returns an updated array. If the index is out of range, the array is unaltered. set 1 7 (fromList [1,2,3]) == fromList [1,7,3]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Array.get``1(System.Int32,``0[])
member.summary: Return `Just` the element at the index or `Nothing` if the index is out of range. get 0 (fromList [0,1,2]) == Just 0 get 2 (fromList [0,1,2]) == Just 2 get 5 (fromList [0,1,2]) == Nothing get -1 (fromList [0,1,2]) == Nothing

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Array.fromList``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Create an array from a `List`.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Array.repeat``1(System.Int32,``0)
member.summary: Creates an array with a given length, filled with a default element. repeat 5 0 == fromList [0,0,0,0,0] repeat 3 "cat" == fromList ["cat","cat","cat"] Notice that `repeat 3 x` is the same as `initialize 3 (always x)`.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Array.initialize``1(System.Int32,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{System.Int32,``0})
member.summary: Initialize an array. `initialize n f` creates an array of length `n` with the element at index `i` initialized to the result of `(f i)`. initialize 4 identity == fromList [0,1,2,3] initialize 4 (\n -> n*n) == fromList [0,1,4,9] initialize 4 (always 0) == fromList [0,0,0,0]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.drop``1(System.Int32,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary:
Drop the first *n* members of a list.
drop 2 [1,2,3,4] == [3,4]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.take``1(System.Int32,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary:
Take the first *n* members of a list.
take 2 [1,2,3,4] == [1,2]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.tail``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary:
Extract the rest of the list.
tail [1,2,3] == Just [2,3] tail [] == Nothing
**Note:** It is usually preferable to use a `case` to deconstruct a `List` because it gives you `(x :: xs)` and you can work with both subparts.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.head``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary:
Extract the first element of a list.
head [1,2,3] == Just 1 head [] == Nothing
**Note:** It is usually preferable to use a `case` to deconstruct a `List` because it gives you `(x :: xs)` and you can work with both subparts.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.sortWith``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Elm.Core.Basics.Order}},Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary:
Sort values with a custom comparison function.
sortWith flippedComparison [1,2,3,4,5] == [5,4,3,2,1]
flippedComparison a b = case compare a b of LT -> GT EQ -> EQ GT -> LT
This is also the most general sort function, allowing you to define any other: `sort == sortWith compare`

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.intersperse``1(``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Places the given value between all members of the given list. intersperse "on" ["turtles","turtles","turtles"] == ["turtles","on","turtles","on","turtles"]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.concatMap``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``1}},Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Map a given function onto a list and flatten the resulting lists. concatMap f xs == concat (map f xs)

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.append``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0},Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Put two lists together. append [1,1,2] [3,5,8] == [1,1,2,3,5,8] append ['a','b'] ['c'] == ['a','b','c'] You can also use [the `(++)` operator](Basics#++) to append lists.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.product(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{System.Int32})
member.summary: Get the product of the list elements. product [2,2,2] == 8 product [3,3,3] == 27 product [] == 1

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.sum(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{System.Int32})
member.summary: Get the sum of the list elements. sum [1,2,3] == 6 sum [1,1,1] == 3 sum [] == 0

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.minimum``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Find the minimum element in a non-empty list. minimum [3,2,1] == Just 1 minimum [] == Nothing

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.maximum``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Find the maximum element in a non-empty list. maximum [1,4,2] == Just 4 maximum [] == Nothing

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.member'``1(``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Figure out whether a list contains a value. member 9 [1,2,3,4] == False member 4 [1,2,3,4] == True

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.any``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,System.Boolean},Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Determine if any elements satisfy some test. any isEven [2,3] == True any isEven [1,3] == False any isEven [] == False

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.all``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,System.Boolean},Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Determine if all elements satisfy some test. all isEven [2,4] == True all isEven [2,3] == False all isEven [] == True

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.reverse``1(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Reverse a list. reverse [1,2,3,4] == [4,3,2,1]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.filterMap``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpOption{``1}},Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary:
Filter out certain values. For example, maybe you have a bunch of strings from an untrusted source and you want to turn them into numbers:
numbers : List Int numbers = filterMap String.toInt ["3", "hi", "12", "4th", "May"] -- numbers == [3, 12]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.foldr``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``1,``1}},``1,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Reduce a list from the right. foldr (+) 0 [1,2,3] == 6 foldr (::) [] [1,2,3] == [1,2,3] So `foldr step state [1,2,3]` is like saying: state |> step 3 |> step 2 |> step 1

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.foldl``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``1,``1}},``1,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Reduce a list from the left. foldl (+) 0 [1,2,3] == 6 foldl (::) [] [1,2,3] == [3,2,1] So `foldl step state [1,2,3]` is like saying: state |> step 1 |> step 2 |> step 3

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.indexedMap``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{System.Int32,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``1}},Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Same as `map` but the function is also applied to the index of each element (starting at zero). indexedMap Tuple.pair ["Tom","Sue","Bob"] == [ (0,"Tom"), (1,"Sue"), (2,"Bob") ]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.cons``1(``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpList{``0})
member.summary: Add an element to the front of a list. 1 :: [2,3] == [1,2,3] 1 :: [] == [1] This operator is pronounced *cons* for historical reasons, but you can think of it like pushing an entry onto a stack.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.range(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Create a list of numbers, every element increasing by one. You give the lowest and highest number that should be in the list. range 3 6 == [3, 4, 5, 6] range 3 3 == [3] range 6 3 == []

member.name: M:Elm.Core.List.repeat``1(System.Int32,``0)
member.summary: Create a list with *n* copies of a value: repeat 3 (0,0) == [(0,0),(0,0),(0,0)]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Result.fromMaybe``2(``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpOption{``1})
member.summary:
Convert from a simple `Maybe` to interact with some code that primarily uses `Results`.
parseInt : String -> Maybe Int
resultParseInt : String -> Result String Int resultParseInt string = fromMaybe ("error parsing string: " ++ toString string) (parseInt string)

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Result.toMaybe``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpResult{``0,``1})
member.summary:
Convert to a simpler `Maybe` if the actual error message is not needed or you need to interact with some code that primarily uses maybes.
parseInt : String -> Result ParseError Int
maybeParseInt : String -> Maybe Int maybeParseInt string = toMaybe (parseInt string)

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Result.mapError``3(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``1},Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpResult{``2,``0})
member.summary:
Transform an `Error` value. For example, say the errors we get have too much information:
parseInt : String -> Result ParseError Int
type alias ParseError = { message : String , code : Int , position : (Int,Int) }
mapError .message (parseInt "123") == Ok 123 mapError .message (parseInt "abc") == Error "char 'a' is not a number"

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Result.andThen``3(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpResult{``1,``2}},Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpResult{``0,``2})
member.summary:
Chain together a sequence of computations that may fail. It is helpful to see its definition:
andThen : (a -> Result e b) -> Result e a -> Result e b andThen callback result = case result of Ok value -> callback value Error msg -> Error msg
This means we only continue with the callback if things are going well. For example, say you need to use (`toInt : String -> Result String Int`) to parse a month and make sure it is between 1 and 12:
toValidMonth : Int -> Result String Int toValidMonth month = if month >= 1 && month <= 12 then Ok month else Error "months must be between 1 and 12"
toMonth : String -> Result String Int toMonth rawString = toInt rawString |> andThen toValidMonth
-- toMonth "4" == Ok 4 -- toMonth "9" == Ok 9 -- toMonth "a" == Error "cannot parse to an Int" -- toMonth "0" == Error "months must be between 1 and 12"
This allows us to come out of a chain of operations with quite a specific error message. It is often best to create a custom type that explicitly represents the exact ways your computation may fail. This way it is easy to handle in your code.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Result.map2``4(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``1,``2}},Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpResult{``0,``3},Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpResult{``1,``3})
member.summary:
Apply a function if both results are `Ok`. If not, the first `Error` will propagate through.
map2 max (Ok 42) (Ok 13) == Ok 42 map2 max (Error "x") (Ok 13) == Error "x" map2 max (Ok 42) (Error "y") == Error "y" map2 max (Error "x") (Error "y") == Error "x"
This can be useful if you have two computations that may fail, and you want to put them together quickly.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Result.map``3(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,``1},Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpResult{``0,``2})
member.summary: Apply a function to a result. If the result is `Ok`, it will be converted. If the result is an `Error`, the same error value will propagate through. map sqrt (Ok 4.0) == Ok 2.0 map sqrt (Error "bad input") == Error "bad input"

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Result.withDefault``2(``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpResult{``0,``1})
member.summary: If the result is `Ok` return the value, but if the result is an `Error` then return a given default value. The following examples try to parse integers. Result.withDefault 0 (Ok 123) == 123 Result.withDefault 0 (Error "no") == 0

The most general way of combining two dictionaries. You provide three accumulators for when a given key appears:
1. Only in the left dictionary. 2. In both dictionaries. 3. Only in the right dictionary.
You then traverse all the keys from lowest to highest, building up whatever you want.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.diff``3(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1},Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``2})
member.summary: Keep a key-value pair when its key does not appear in the second dictionary.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.intersect``3(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1},Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``2})
member.summary: Keep a key-value pair when its key appears in the second dictionary. Preference is given to values in the first dictionary.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.union``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1},Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1})
member.summary: Combine two dictionaries. If there is a collision, preference is given to the first dictionary.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.fromList``2
member.summary: Convert an association list into a dictionary. -}

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.toList``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1})
member.summary: Convert a dictionary into an association list of key-value pairs, sorted by keys.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.values``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1})
member.summary:
Get all of the values in a dictionary, in the order of their keys.
values (fromList [(0,"Alice"),(1,"Bob")]) == ["Alice", "Bob"]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.keys``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1})
member.summary:
Get all of the keys in a dictionary, sorted from lowest to highest.
keys (fromList [(0,"Alice"),(1,"Bob")]) == [0,1]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.partition``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``1,System.Boolean}},Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1})
member.summary: Partition a dictionary according to some test. The first dictionary contains all key-value pairs which passed the test, and the second contains the pairs that did not.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.filter``2
member.summary: Keep only the key-value pairs that pass the given test.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.foldr``3(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``1,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``2,``2}}},``2,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1})
member.summary:
Fold over the key-value pairs in a dictionary from highest key to lowest key.
getAges : Dict String User -> List String getAges users = Dict.foldr addAge [] users
addAge : String -> User -> List String -> List String addAge _ user ages = user.age :: ages
-- getAges users == [28,19,33]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.foldl``3(Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``1,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{``2,``2}}},``2,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1})
member.summary:
Fold over the key-value pairs in a dictionary from lowest key to highest key.
getAges : Dict String User -> List String getAges users = Dict.foldl addAge [] users
addAge : String -> User -> List String -> List String addAge _ user ages = user.age :: ages
-- getAges users == [33,19,28]

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.map``3
member.summary: Apply a function to all values in a dictionary.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.singleton``2(``0,``1)
member.summary: Create a dictionary with one key-value pair. -}

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.update``2(``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpOption{``1},Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpOption{``1}},Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1})
member.summary: Update the value of a dictionary for a specific key with a given function. -}

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.remove``2
member.summary: Remove a key-value pair from a dictionary. If the key is not found, no changes are made.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.isEmpty``2
member.summary:
Determine if a dictionary is empty.
isEmpty empty == True

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.insert``2(``0,``1,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1})
member.summary: Insert a key-value pair into a dictionary. Replaces value when there is a collision.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.size``2(Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1})
member.summary: Determine the number of key-value pairs in the dictionary.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.member'``2(``0,Microsoft.FSharp.Collections.FSharpMap{``0,``1})
member.summary: Determine if a key is in a dictionary.

member.name: M:Elm.Core.Dict.get``2
member.summary:
Get the value associated with a key. If the key is not found, return `Nothing`. This is useful when you are not sure if a key will be in the dictionary.
animals = fromList [ ("Tom", Cat), ("Jerry", Mouse) ] get "Tom" animals == Just Cat get "Jerry" animals == Just Mouse get "Spike" animals == Nothing
